text:
The main section of Cousteau Base’s ring is a massive promenade; and you stroll aimlessly through the exhibits on theoretical models of herd-cetacean intelligence and sociology, the dusty, grandiose old plans for an agricultural colony floating on the Odessan ocean.

Small kiosks around the ring sell flash-fried fish- and squidlike creatures, native to Odessa but tank-grown on station, with an assortment of spicy-sweet sauces. You wonder, as you suck the last greasy traces off your fingers, what the aboriginal cetaceans would make of this canned overview of their existence.

All in all, though, not a bad way to spend some time and a few spare credits, you think as you return to your ship.

"Good to see you, commander. Business before pleasure, please; one tries to keep a schedule."
OR
The screen flickers, and $personName smiles at you broadly as the comm channel stabilizes.

"I don't suppose you'd have time to pull alongside and help me down the rest of this bottle - it's an excellent vintage."
OR
"An unexpected pleasure, certainly, commander, but I have business. Is there something you need?"
OR
The channel stabilizes and $personName breaks into a sly grin. 
"My, my, commander, you do look rather... dashing, but I'm afraid I'm on company time right now."

"I recommend you find easier prey, commander - I have no intention of giving in without a fight."
OR
"The longer you push other spacers around, the more likely you'll find someone who pushes back."
OR
"I have no doubt your fleet could destroy mine, but I promise you, commander- you'll know you've been in a fight."

"So it has come to this. Very well - the High Guard may die; but it does not surrender."

The comm channel closes.
OR
"So be it. May the victory go to the better strategist."

The comm link cuts out.
OR
"I expect one of us will live to regret this. Forgive me for hoping that it won't be you."

The channel snaps off abruptly.

"You have been identified as an enemy of the Dassault-Mikoyan corporation. No quarter is expected, and certainly none will be given."
OR
"There are only two powers in the sector - the sword, and the mind."

The enemy $personRank pauses theatrically.

"And in the long run, the sword always falls to the mind. You've been living by the sword for... quite some time, commander. Time we put an end to that."
OR
"You didn't think this through, commander; you and your crew will pay a terrible price for that."

"You're speaking to a representative of Dassault-Mikoyan Engineering."
OR
"Greetings from Dassault-Mikoyan Engineering."
"I don't think you understand the gravity of your position, captain. You're on the Company's wanted list; I suggest you find some other volume of space to play in, before you get hurt."

"It seems you're already commissioned by $theOtherCommissionFaction. I'm afraid we don't allow our licensed hunter-warriors to moonlight; you'll have to resign that commission before we can accept your application."
"I'm sorry, but it says here that you don't meet our criteria. We only commission hunter-warriors with clean records in Dassault-Mikoyan space."

"Hmm, yes, you are in good standing and none of our databases have tagged you as a troublemaker.

Accepting a commission from Dassault-Mikoyan is a serious matter. You will be called on to guard our trade and defend our worlds; to uphold the rule of law and the Declaration of Values as laid down by the Nikolaev System Authority, and finally, to fight the Blade Breakers and bring their Council to justice as an auxiliary of the Sixth Bureau.

You have the right to resign your commission as an independent hunter-warrior at any time. After resignation, you may no longer call on our legal or diplomatic protection from any enemies you may have made in our service."
"If you wish to continue, please be aware that hunter-warrior annual fatality rates have in the past reached as high as 78%. Here is your contract. Do you accept?"
"Very well. On behalf of the Nikolaev System Authority and the Dassault-Mikoyan corporation, your comissioned hunter-warrior license has been granted. Welcome, starfarer."
"Anything else I can do for you?"

"Yes, I understand. It is dangerous work, and it requires great skill, and a certain... élan, you might say, to face off against our enemies. Certainly no one would blame you for turning down the deadly risks as well as the rewards, captain.

Is there anything else I can do for you?"
"Are you certain? A hunter-warrior license is rarely granted to fully independent captains such as yourself; no few of them would kill for it."

"I can see there's no changing your mind. On behalf of the Company, you have our sincere thanks for your services to date.

Your retinal patterns will be deregistered from our database, and your legal immunity has been revoked."
"I'm glad to hear you've changed your mind. We can always use a few good pilots to keep the spacelanes clear for honest trade."

"My unit is at your disposal."
OR
"A pleasure to speak with an ally. What is your business?"
OR
"I've been authorized to offer you assistance in accordance with general orders. State your request."

"There will be no surrender, tyrant. We are not in the habit of giving up without a fight."
OR
"Kill us all, if you must, but we'll never tolerate your corrupted and decadent sector."

"So be it, we fight. Allegiance or death - Blade Breakers!"
OR
"Forward to victory, or forward to death! For the Blade Breakers!"
OR
"We are permitted to die, not to surrender."

"You have been identified as a threat to the aims and ideals of the Blade Breakers. Make whatever rituals are necessary; you will be exterminated."
OR
"Very well. If you will not surrender your ships, prepare to be expunged from the face of the universe."

"I command an Active Service Unit of the Blade Breakers. Be brief."
OR
"What is your reason for contacting the Blade Breakers?"
OR
"Your presence here is premature. We battle the Sixth Bureau for possession of the Substance and supremacy of doctrine."

script:
PrintDescription 1
AddText "The interior of the ancient sporeship has been cleaned, but otherwise retains the wear and patina of age that lends it more solemn dignity than any decoration could hope for. These aren't precisely hallowed grounds, but they resist trivialization - and decorating the site of generations-long desperation to escape the clutches of the Domain is surely that, a trivialization of what was sacrificed, and survived, to bring the Fleet here. You get the sense that civilians are distinctly unwelcome, but you're treated with a brusque, functional courtesy by everyone you interact with."
ShowDefaultVisual
FireBest dcp_magellan_blackcollarBaseMainOptions

text:
In contrast to the empty triumphalism of other military memorials you've seen, this tomb is a simple, functional obelisk, engraved to about a third of the total height with the names of fallen Blackcollar soldiers, and placed in the center of a vast, otherwise empty compartment. Every death is memorialized; no distinction of gender, ethnicity, rank, or class is made, no mention of how honorable or craven a death may have been. They are simply recorded, laser-etched into the memorial in order as they fall by pitiless automated scribes, and indexed so that the heads-up displays of any visitor can pick out a name if so requested.

You leave after a while, uncomfortable in the presence of so much death, with so little context.

text:
You walk down the marked route, following the careful signs, until you come to the station’s largest communal hall.

Inside, one wall of the vast space has been decorated with paper and imitation-silk flowers, predominantly purple or red. Around and among the flowers, sometimes layers deep, have been placed a variety of 2D and 3D images, short holos, news-flimsy sheets, smart-paper sheets, and small screens. Each activates as you pass near enough to it to trigger a sensor; you see pictures of young men and women cradling carbines, news articles, poetry, proclamations, speeches… and glimpses, though only briefly, of the chaotic, bloody ruck of the first Leveller Uprising show through. Little to none of the memorial references the station itself; a few brief notes seem to be related to the construction of the habitat, but nothing else.

The Uprising may have been defeated, but no movement that can inspire such a memorial can be said to have been beaten. And certainly the pressures that created the Levellers still exist in Magellan society…
You've left equipment recently, so leaving another stash at this time might attract unwanted attention.

text:
The hall is mostly empty, but a few merchanter families with children in tow are singing and playing instruments around a tray of delicious-smelling food. They refuse to hear your protests to the contrary and beckon you over to share in food, chatter, and several swigs out of an unlabelled bottle.

...There once was a ship that plied the stars,
And the name of the ship was the Lily of Mars,
The hyper storms ripped her up and down,
Take hold, ye spacers, take hold...

...Soon may the salvageman come,
To bring us drugs and organs and guns,
One day, when the scavenging’s done,
We’ll take our leave and go.

After a few more raucous songs and far too many voices imploring you to stay for 'just one more drink!', you bid your hosts farewell and wander back to your ship's berth, belly warm with the rough liquor and with new, happy memories.
You've been around pirates, smugglers, and other types of criminals often enough, and know how to act so they see you as one of their own.
You've gained a measure of notoriety in the underworld of Magellan space, and know how to throw your weight around to get what you want.
You've proven useful to some of the leaders of the various criminal enterprises in the Sector. Harassing you is more trouble than it's worth.
Both your prowess in battle and your barbecue skills are legendary, and your connections and influence in the Magellan underworld, enviable.
The Herd, as a whole, only tend to view you with distrust. Incidentally, that's more than can be said for how they see fellow captains.
The Herd are generally only inhospitable towards you, which means you've already made a name for yourself as someone whose interests might align with theirs.
Your name is not known to Herd captains, for good or ill. Mostly ill, as they'll attack you without a second thought if the opportunity arises, although Herd bases will gladly trade with you.

You've made a name for yourself by hunting down the Herd's members; Herd bases are no longer willing to trade with you. There's little practical difference in the attitude of Herd captains, as they were already willing to kill you given the chance.
